repnme.cdata!:
Nicaragua - Second Road Rehabilitation and
            Maintenance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome for the Second Road
            Rehabilitation and Maintenance Project for Nicaragua was
            highly satisfactory, the sustainability was highly likely,
            the institutional development impact was substantial, and
            the Bank and borrower performance were both highly
            satisfactory. Following are lessons learned from the
            project: IDA continued presence in the transport sector
            helped to enhance the supervision effectiveness and deepen
            understanding of transport issues. Proactive supervision and
            restructuring of the project as soon as critical emergencies
            occurred were essential to achieve the development
            objectives. This type of program offers several important
            advantages compared to other traditional road gravel or
            asphalt rehabilitation work methods. When there is proper
            coordination among donor agencies and institutional
            organizations, it can help to ensure that efforts are not
            duplicated while providing leverage for investments. The
            micro-enterprises program was highly successful and enabled
            many previously unemployed rural families to obtain a steady
            income while carrying out economically justifiable road
            conservation works.

repnme.cdata!:
Nicaragua - Second Road Rehabilitation and
            Maintenance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the Second
            Road Rehabilitation and Maintenance Project is to improve
            the efficiency of road transportation in Nicaragua. The
            project components are: 1) Managua - El Rama road
            rehabilitation component, sections Portezuelo - San Benito
            and Muhan - El Rama; 2) The road maintenance component
            includes the execution by contract of about 600 km of
            periodic maintenance, road rehabilitation, and spot
            improvement on selected roads; and 3) The institutional and
            training development component includes training, studies,
            technical assistance and consultant services to assist the
            Ministry of Construction and Transport (MCT): i) to prepare
            economically justified road improvement programs; ii) to
            implement the pavement management system; iii) to establish
            and operate the road maintenance fund; iv) to supervise the
            road rehabilitation works; v) strengthen the management of
            road by contract; vi) to carry out staff training and vii)
            to carry out a road safety study, reforestation study, and
            feasibility and detailed engineering studies.
